wikipedia_page.main: Sir Arthur William Black (28 February 1863 – 13 July 1947) was an English lace manufacturer from Nottingham and a Liberal Party politician who served in local government in Nottingham before holding a seat in the House of Commons from 1906 to 1918.

link_mentions.page: List of MPs elected in the January 1910 United Kingdom general election

response: * Arthur Black (humorist) (1943—2018), Canadian writer and radio humorist
* Arthur Black (unionist politician) (1888–1968), Unionist politician and judge in Northern Ireland
* Arthur Black (Liberal politician) (1863–1947), Member of Parliament (MP) for Biggleswade, 1906–1918

He was elected to the House of Commons at the 1895 general election as the Liberal Unionist Member of Parliament (MP) for the Biggleswade division of Bedfordshire. Compton was re-elected unopposed in 1900, but at the 1906 general election he was defeated by the Liberal Party candidate Arthur Black. He was returned to the Commons at the January 1910 election as Unionist MP for Brentford,Craig, page 344 and held the seat until his resignation on 15 March 1911 by the procedural device of appointment as Steward of the Chiltern Hundreds.

Townley was adopted as Conservative candidate for Mid Bedfordshire on 18 November 1918, where he received the Coalition Coupon in opposition to Sir Arthur Black, incumbent MP for Biggleswade who was a Liberal supporter of H. H. Asquith."Election Candidates", The Times, 19 November 1918, p. 8. He won the seat with a majority of 1,721,"Debrett's Illustrated House of Commons and Judicial Bench" 1921, p. 178. In Parliament, Townley concentrated on agricultural issues on which he had professional knowledge; he was a member of a delegation from the Agriculture Committee of the House of Commons to see the Prime Minister in July 1919."The Future Of Agriculture", The Times, 31 July 1919, p. 6.
Sir Arthur Black; Liberal Party politician (28 February 1863 – 13 July 1947)
*Arthur Black (Liberal politician) (1863–1947), Nottingham businessman and Member of Parliament (MP) for Biggleswade 1906–1918
